The journey to Berlin Schonefeld Airport was very good. We took the S-Bahn from Central Berlin to the airport. 

We arrived 3 hours before departure, so more than enough time. But, what became immediately clear was that the facilities were dated even before getting past check-in. The architecture looked Cold War era. When we arrived at Check-in and had put our bags through security screening, we then went to check-in our hold luggage. Unfortunately, the counters at check-in in Terminal A at Schonefeld were not like systems used by similar low-cost carriers at other airports, where several counters are used for the all flights of that airline at once. We had a counter and a Milan flight was currently using it. It wasn't for another hour that it finally opened. 

At security it was a similar problem of cold war infrastructure. It took a further 10-15 minutes to get through to airside departures. When I got air side what was obvious to me was the lack of seating in the food and retail area, with people sitting against the walls on either side waiting to be allowed to go their respective departure lounge. 

I went to get food for breakfast, but everywhere was busy. Then with over an hour before the gate was scheduled to close, I was requested to go to Gate 62 for boarding. When I got there, I found that I had to show my passport, which was unusual compared to other airports I have used. I then waited in this departure lounge for FR1639 to East Midlands for at least 30 minutes. This for me was the weirdest and worst airport experience ever. 

In the future, if I have to travel to Berlin, I will have to hope that the new Berlin Brandenburg Airport will have opened by then.

This due in part because my flight used the new low cost section of the airport. Immigration took longer than I expected from an European airport. Once I had reached baggage reclaim, it was quick to start and I quickly received my bag. 

Travelling from the airport, you can take a taxi or public transport. I took the S-Bahn to Central Berlin from the nearby dedicated Schonefeld station. The station is not next to the airport and a walk of a couple of minutes is required between the two. 

I would recommend not arriving in the evening as services do become less frequent. As well as that, if you are not used to using the rail network in Berlin, It is quite difficult to navigate compared to the London Underground and the ticketing system is not easy either. Unfortunately there was no one there to help us with ticketing, as it is automated.

The arrival in to Schonefeld was ok.

Avoid this horrible airport at all cost.

This is a review of departure from terminal 3. Access to terminal 3 isn't easy. The closest you can get is to Roissypole if you come by tube (RER) from Paris, which is 10 minutes walking distance from terminal 3. In my case it was worse since I came be coach due to strikes and it dropped me terminal 1. The journey from terminal 1 to terminal 3 took me 15 minutes running all over the place. So better assume 20 minutes. Security departure wasn't clearly marked inside the terminal despite being it a very small one. Security took me 15 minutes to finish. Police border checks was very quick since I was the only one. On the airside part there isn't much to do. Usual boutiques and I think a couple of food places. Boarding is always done by bus in terminal 3 which is a little bit painful.
Terminal 1, good access, nice retro feeling, not much choice in terms of fast food, security check at each finger very bad design (though good for aircraft turnarounds).
Love the airport.  For architecture lovers it is a delight of a design. The pedestrian flow is excellent, and if you seem lost there are many employees that can be of assistance.
Departing from terminal 2E. Security check was a bit long. Food providers not as numerous as one would expect from the main terminal of Air France. Terminal is very quiet.

Departing terminal 2D.
Terminal is small so moving inside of it is quick. Security is quite efficient and immigration process is very quick. You don't have a lot of food choices especially once you have crossed immigration (which is way after you crossed security). Toilets are clean. Terminal isn't noisy.
Reaching the airport is somehow easy but disappointing for a big city like Paris. The best option is to take RER B from Châtelet or Gare du Nord. If you're lucky you will have the one that doesn't stop at all between Gare du Nord and the airport. Otherwise you'll stop in some of the suburban towns North of Paris which will increase your journey's time.

Arrived to terminal 3. I used to hate this terminal mainly due to lengthy immigration process at arrival. But now they put automatic gates which make this part much more smooth. The main drawback of this terminal is that public transportation aren't close and you need to walk almost 10 minutes to reach Central station close to terminal 1. Walking is done outside which, in winter, can be quite cold.

Arrival to terminal 2D. Exiting the terminal is quite quick since it's a very small one. Crossing immigration took some time since no automatic gates and only two agents. No distinction between European and non European passports. Due to public transportation strike in Paris I had to take the private bus company called "le bus direct" which is quite expensive. Need to change terminal and need to wait quite long before bus arrived.

Pas de coupe file ou mal contrôle plus de monde qu en économique..

Nice modern building with excellent facilities but staff are second rate overall and are very slow to deal with customers
Starting to look tired, but the main criticism is the sheer lack of food outlets in Terminal 2K. The satellite terminal 2G is really basic and looks unfinished

Confusing as always. Annoying that you have to clear security again, even if transferring. I try to avoid CDG when possible. Especially the signage and way finding are terrible. Automatic passport gates are usually out of order. Staff is not particularly friendly.

Very fast transfer arriving from a intercontinental flight connecting to a European flight. Smooth processing at passing Schengen passport control by using Parafe automated check. Walk from 2E-K to 2F took about 15 mins.

Consistently the worst airport in the world. To make my connection, I had to go through security twice: first they check you as you go to the transfer bus and then it turns out that the only way to enter the Schengen area at 2D is by going through the check-in area. Terrible food - only croissants or super-expensive 'healthy' options.
They insisted weighting my bag, before the security check, and it costed finally 100 euros to check in my bag.

This is such a large airport. I would not like to have a short connection here. I used the Air France lounge in 2F and was severely disappointed. There weren't many food options (nothing hot), and the coffee machine only half fills the cups. The food was replenished quickly, but as I said, there's a limited choice.

In terms of third-party catering, there are a few places but most seem to offer baguettes and salads. After travelling for 14 hours, I wanted more than just a baguette or a slice of quiche.
For international trips (out of EU), I recommend to be minimun 3 hour before. The airport is huge and theres a lot o people on the lines to passport check and then to the security control.
AF lounges are on the ground floor. Conveniently near the gate, but view and light is because of that location less.
Long queues at security check since domestic flight transfer escalators leads you to airport main entrance. Where you are mixed up with all other travelers departing

The lay-out of this airport is absolutely inefficient. I arrived from Oslo in the left half of Terminal 2F, where we were led to the other half of Terminal 2F to be processed through immigration. Oslo and Paris are both within Schengen, so I was surprised I had to show my passport again. The staff was rude and dismissive. Then I had to walk all the way back to the other half of Terminal 2F again. On the way to Oslo a few days earlier, this was just a matter of clearing a flight of stairs.

Flight from CDG 2F. 
Access is convenient from Paris center with Roissybus (from Opera) and alternatively by RER B or taxi.
Security check is fine but they have added an additional check on cabin luggage weight and size for passengers who checked in online (instead of doing it at the gate), and since there’s only one row for this check, it creates a bottleneck.
Terminal 2F has two piers, one on the left coming out from security check and one on the right (they used to be called F1 and F2). The one on the right has many more restaurants, the one on the left only snack bars and sandwich outlets.
The big issue with terminal 2F is that the area near the gates is too small for people to queue and there are not enough seats.

I have been against any transit via airport for years but i must admit that it has really improved a lot. It is much brighter than ever, clear to navigate from each terminal, easy, clean and smell good. There is a lot of shop inside and price are acceptable. Wifi is working well with no time limit. Spotting thru windows is not easy but manageable.
At the night they didn't let us to pass security control and wait in lounge between our connected flights. So we had to sleep on chairs.
Terminal 2G is not really Terminal 2. Terminal 4 should be a correct name as it's a completely separate building.

Terminal 1 at CDG is an absolutely joke. Cramped spaces that can't efficiently cope with the number of passengers they are trying to process on an early Sunday afternoon. Once cleared through security, there is only one place to buy a sandwich. No restaurants or bars etc.

Only few restaurants in 2F
Only AF lounge in 2F
Had to go to L to find a Priority Pas lounge.
The Priority Pas lounge with a poor selection of food.
Was not initially not allowed to go back from 2F to L , but was allowed after finding a supervisor.
It seems the staff is poorly trainde and arrogant on top!

Quick arrival (no traffic at this time). Fast baggage drop off at terminal 2F (all automated). Modern, big terminal, lots of lighting and windows with great apron views. Fast security and passport control.

Nasty terminal, rude staff, unclean, honestly the nastiest International Airport I've flown I to (T3 that is, the Air France terminal is wonderful) also don't take the train from the airport, they cram you in and held our train for an hour to cram more people into
Not fun to pass through this airport in terminal 2, specially if you have to go to 2E, L or those far away terminals.

No restaurants in the terminal 2E except three small cafes with some fastfood.

Also getting the airport by RER is a kind of challenge, all the announcements are in French, the public transport system is very complicated and lacks navigation much. Even of you find a proper line (B), there're two different routes on the same line, so you might easily get the wrong train.

Long walk and internal transit train required between arriving at terminal 2E and getting to the L gates which are on a satellite area away from the main terminal. Security is done after passport control and for the L gates the security is done in the satellite area after you’ve been on the transit train, which I did find a bit odd...

Il faut jamais prendre Hop. Leur service était horrible, il y avait pas de climatisation, il faisait hyper chaud.

Never fly Hop. Their service was horrible, there was no AC in the plane, it was miserable.

Terminal 2G (HOP !) has unsettling late gate announcements and very limited seating at gate. Two years ago I nearly missed my flight because of a frozen flight display screen, having to leave my beer behind and running to the gate.

Airport is a bit crowded, but clean and walking distances for connecting flights within the Schengen-zone are small. There are some shops and there are many seats inside the terminal. The lounge is basic, but everything you need is there.
This note refers to the terminal G, very poor and without good connexion with other terminals/train/metro
Functional, well organized, good lounge (air France hall K). All went well although there seemed to be a small number of police at the sky priority passport control.
Low cost terminal 3. Bus to the plane, under heavy rain. They took away my bag when I was boarding the plane claiming no to have room for it.

I spent several hours at CDG on a connection from AA to AF.  Not a lot of shopping choices aside from food and drink - at least not in Terminal 2F.  I was looking since my bags didn't make my flight to CDG on AA.
AVOID going on an Air France/HOP-Mix journey as this means you will have to change planes and go landsline hence security again.

A stupidly complicated airport to navigate. Because of their very poor signalisation for transit passengers, we almost missed our connecting flight even though we had 70 minutes.
CDG has constantly proven to be the worst airport in Europe.

Terminal 2A at CDG in itself is ok for the most part, though as in the rest of CDG the experience is different every time you go there. Parking is fine, but not easy to access (for Terminal 2A), the staff can be nice (I had a really nice person that time at check-in), but can sometimes be very rude. Terminal 2A had a lot of expensive stores from various French fashion brands (even though it is more expensive than anywhere else). Food options are ok.

- Very modern and beautiful of the design.

We only were here to transfer for our flight to Amsterdam, found the airport easy enough to navigate through, although we had done a bit of prior research online so knew where we needed to be going. We only had about 1 hour here so didn't really get to see or do much at the airport

Overall an awful experience and to be avoided at all costs. To whoever runs CDG take a trip to Schiphol and see how it's done.

Avoid at all costs.

My flight was in the Terminal 1 of Paris CDG airport. The oldest part of the airport. Indeed, you can feel that it's not anymore in the present. The check-in was great since there was much people. The security was great too. But the waiting part wasn't great for an international airport. The duty free was very small, lot's of people were waiting for flights and there isn't much place to seat. Moreover, if you have the back luck and you arrive during a boarding process you can barely walk.

Good airport but it depends what terminal you are in. I've been in some terminals that are all luxury and others that are very budget airline looking. Travelling too the airport is easy with RER and the airport itself looks pretty good. Runs fairly smooth and well signed.
One has to spend a lot of time here in order to find to pass a passport control or for connecting flights.

Since i was in transfer from Prague i only have to say that the Lounge at gates K is very good: lot of food but some staff are watching what you are taking and if you take too much food they come to you and say that you have to give the food back and unfriendly staff. Wifi sucks in the airport

The RER train from the city's core is easy to use and comforatbly delivered us to CDG. There is a bit of an outdoor walk from the train terminal to Terminal 3. Checkin was relatively easy and the security check was quick & efficient. There are a couple of well stocked duty-free stores in the terminal, a Relay news and gift stand with some prepackaged food, and a Pret A Manger for fresher options. The waiting lounge is large and has fun free video game consoles (PacMan or Donkey Kong anyone?) and some PS3 consoles too. Departure form CDG T3 is much better than arrival there, which was awful with no services available.

The EU line at border control doesn't cover all EU countries, in fact it only cover about 4 or 5 so make sure you're in the right line. The staff were rude and didn't seem to know what they were doing either. Thankfully the airline staff are nothing like the airport staff.
T3 is horrible. There are no services on arrival and a long walk outdoors to the connecting train to T1.

Very, very poor food choices in the departure area (just a few very expensive and crowded options). By 8pm already mostly sold out.
Getting to the airport very, very painful as usual (RER B broken). I can't think of many major airports with such poor public transport options.

No more stopovers in CDG! Several big planes (full!) come in the morning and only two or three immigration gates opened for so many people. Due to this situation everybody is late for the connecting flight!

Prior to arrival, check the airport map or you will get loose. Since years, it is getting worse and worse. Not organized, no clear signage, border control is a disaster. Choose definitively an other airport for transit. GOOD LUCK :-)

People working here are so rude. Fair enough 6 am start is early to be at work...but they got more sleep then I did in economy on a 9 hour flight then I did from KNB

A nice airport. Huge though. If you fly in from Basel you're basically outside at the Terminal which is the farthest away - if you need to get to the main terminal for example you need time. Always plan enough time for this (45 minutes are not enough, my experience)! Staff is friendly.

I did not have any time to check out Food and retail service, WiFi and Lounge, hence no rating.

Terminal 2D in CDG is not the best. It feels crowded all the time and doesn't offer much shopping and dining places.

Aéroport peu agréable.

Add to this dozens of kids with careless parents and you get the perfect cocktail for the beginning of a memorable trip. Food and drinks are available from various shops but prices are pure robery. Check-in at automate a breeze. Security was fast and courteous. Lounge is also often overcrowded at T2F and food / drinks offer not always renewed.

Changing of planes from Terminal G (Schengen) to international flights has substantially improved over the past year. Separate bus lines for the terminal, with separate waiting queues, shorter driving distance.

Terminal 3 assez lugubre.

Terminal 1 is so unique. The only terminal in the prod you can see 2 sign coin to the same direction by 2 different ways. Allow some time to enjoy
At least morning security check goes nicely at an International airport. Public transport connections to CDG from Paris obviously very good.

Security Checks and Immigrations are shameful. Security Checks agents maybe think that they are super heroes or something like that and should try to see how it works abroad instead of annoying people all the time. Immigration officers are not enough, queue is way too long !
A very good airport. A very sympathic staff, good facilities. The access to CDG is very easy (TGV, subway, bus and car !)

Poor choice of food outlets in Terminal 2D, limited space and patchy wifi. Not what you'd expect from the main airport in Paris. Kept waiting in a stiflingly hot corridor to board aircraft for 15 minutes

Start to love the airport again. Clean, fast to get through, with great food on the way and reliable free WiFi.

Shuttle busses to the airport are expensive. Terminal 1: Not much shops in airport as i expected. Terminal is really a labyrinth. Not every interactive map is working. Wifi is ok.
Old, not enough seats for waiting passengers. Mainly chaotic situation when more plane board or disembark at similar time. Poor communication

What a shed of an airport. Flight would have been on time if we didn't land in a different postcode to the terminal (12 min taxy)

Ohne of the worst Airports I've ever been to. Totale crowded with so less space for 8 Gates! Only good thing is the really  interesting architecture.
80 minutes from wheels down to being out of the airport.  2 passport control booths open for EU passport holders for all of terminal 2

Immigration very slow, even for Sky Priority, one official dealing with Priority, bio-passport, disabled & airport workers, general line was much faster. Give yourself at least 2 hours for transit. AF lounge in terminal 2E, very good WiFi, and plenty food & drink available.

CDG still "welcomes" Schengen-zone arrivals with occasional passport control to "enter the Schenhen zone" (nice joke). This would not be a problem itself, but the number of customs agents is obviously not adjusted - be prepared for looong queues ramdomly.

Be aware, this is the worst airport in Europe! Rude staff, long queues, damaged luggage, terrible bus connections between terminals, no strollers for lend while in transit. We will really try hard to avoid this place in future!

I am sure this is the worst airport in Europe. This time totally destroyed 2 luggage pieces (and they were quality sturdy hard things) - they came with holes in them, and the third piece was just scratched heavily. Flying in Business class with AF is the best!.

Sky priority check in(Sky Team alliance), really works in CDG Airport.

Paris CDG is increasing its service and the old Terminal 1 is becaming very amazing.

Elend lange Busfahrt vom Satellitenterminal HOP zum International Terminal. Wir mussten dann auch noch ca. 15 Minuten im Bus mit ausgeschalteter Klimaanlage warten, da niemand da war der die Tür zum Terminal geöffnet hat.

Most power outlets don't work. Comfortable seating. Free WiFi. Playstations.

Access to the Icares Lounge with my premium ticket Norwegian. Very good lounge. Good food, and pretty hostesses.
It is always busy, not very confortable the bus to change betwen gates. There had been the terrible accident of the 9525 of Germanwings, so the airport was caos.

Great airport, just large and a little difficult to get around if you are non-revving and have to switch terminals to try another flight, because they won't let you go to another terminal with a ticket for a flight heading to another one.
Really nice airport, kinda overcroweded but that is simply only because it is very popular and the biggest airport in France. Very nice Lounge and seats, very comfortable and makes you feel at home.

This A320 was not well kept at all and had not TVs...and very cramped. It appears that it was one of the older A320's...the flight was delayed for half an ahour due to unknown reasons and we finally departed about 1215pm. The flight was totally filled but very pleasant despite the seating conditions and smell. The flight attendants were extremly friendly and well best part...free cocktails..again!....

Our AF A320 touched down in Barcelona at around 145pm...to partly sunny skies and 60 degree temperatures...quite a change from the 30 degree temps in Paris!

This flight was definitely my most delayed. When I was getting ready to head to security I saw on the departure boards Retardé (delayed) for my flight. I still went through Passport Control, Border Control and Security and I headed to Gates 20-28 as we got no information. At about 1700 we got food vouchers. My uncle text from ORK that our plane (EI-DEL) had gone tech and they would have to bring a substitute plane. The plane came from DUB to ORK then carried the outbound passengers to CDG. We finally got on EI-DVJ at about 2100 hours and we were in Cork for 2200 hours. I enjoyed my day because I am a planespotter but if I was not we were in a room for 6 hours with no information on when we would be getting out of there. All that gates 20-28 had was a coffee shop a vending machine, a souvenir shop, wifi and a window for planespotting.

Bagus, tetapi mohon tingkatkan kenyamanan dan keindahan serta keramaiannya harap dikurangi. Terima Kasih. Dan juga terima kasih atas Jasa kepada Pihak Angkasa Pura II serta yang mendukung terlaksananya acara sedekahan ini. Terima kasih.

The airport is being renovated, hopefully the service will be increased after the renovation is finished. However the service now is quite adequate, maybe it need improvement on check in service area to minimize the queue

Overcrowded, international terminal design great. Ease of access with signs etc, Great ,free (and fast) wifi offered. Immigration and customs processing quick and efficient. Good variety of stores and outlets but not much was open.
i like. love this airlines.
The domestic section of Garuda's flights are not as polished as their international section.

Airport is generally okay. Transfer was not so smooth, signs for transfer leads you to a gate not a transfer desk. Staff don't seem to be so experienced in dealing with transfers. They wanted me to go through immigration and check in again.
Smooth
T3 deserve this 4 stars
Why are the officers so clumsy?
Nothing changed much despite the ongoing work. Speed up the renovation Angkasa Pura II!
New terminal pretty good on arrival.
Nice T3
Poor public transport. Can't imagine how uncomfortable if I was a foreigner who just come for first time in this airport. Very long queue for taxis

Огромный аэропорт! С места прилета и регистрации идти пришлось 15мин. Зал ожидания, где можно присесть, только после прохождения таможенного контроля, до этого времени доступны парочка лавочек...видать потому что здешние жители любят сидеть на полу.
many brokers

The airport is ok and nothing special. Immigration is a bit complicated because you have to purchase your Visa on arrival. If you dont have any cash with you the will escort you to the nearest cash mashine what was actually very kind of them.
It has significantly improved. You can now access all gates, which before was restricted and made no sense.
It's "outdated" because it was built with old Javanese architecture in mind. The garden is off limits, but it the best maintained garden in Indonesia, without any foreign help.
Extremely outdated.
An outdated airport.
Terminal 2D, Gate D51.
Very poor airport for a stop over with not many things to do to keep you interested for 7 hours
Terminal 3 is nice, terminal 2 is okay, terminal 1 is old and dirty. Porters, taxi drivers and shoeshine boys are pushy but behind security it´s fine and facilities are good.

im not sure if i like Soekarno hatta airport. mishandled my luggage, have to pay for a tax even though it was just a transit. no transit terminal that i have to go out and checkin formy next flight. certainly not good for a connecting flight journey.
Normal good.747 is always nice
Heavy traffic jams. A lunch can cost u 250,00 rupiah

FCO.opinion: Rome Fiumicino operation on Coronavirus time, police checks and some bureaucracy, but everything working fast and fine, because there were so few of us, travelers. On transit to Brazil.

Check in for this flight was a mess because the flight was delayed. There was no reason given. Later, Alitalia said it was because of weather over the airport, yet EVERY other airline took off on time...and I know because I was in that airport for 7 hours watching the monitors and planes.

It's been a few years since I've been to Rome. Last time I was at this airport it was under major construction and VERY dirty.

Now, this airport is GORGEOUS. The shops and cafes in the terminal are INCREDIBLE.

How many airports do you do you know of where you see chefs making fresh pizza by hand?
To find a business lounge for B gates is a challenge. The signa are visible but misleading sometimes like turm left directly to ... rest rooms
The waiting areas around the gates are dark and the ceilings seem low. You also need to walk a lot, with no moving walkways.

Hot as hell. AC not enough.
Due to immigration I almost lost my flight. It was a bless that I spealk Italian fluently.

This airport has been modernizing during these years and I can say it's now a very good one. You can find anything you need being it full of shops, restaurants, charging stations, toilets, info points every few meters and a fast free Wi-Fi. I'm very satisfied with this airport.
If they bus you to your flight from the gate, you will wait for a long time on or waiting for one. Then it's a long ride to the actual airplane.
Immigration is a mess for non-Shengen flights. Be aware that you can easily spend several hours in queue

The airport improved a lot since my last visit back in 2016. Something that captured my attention was the passport control. The line was empty, when we arrived an Italian border official called us and -without even looking at the picture of the passport- stamped our passports. That’s a dangerous practice, but very usual at Italy.
T3 windows are fully blocked to see the aircraft movements at the airport. Some of the retail services staff are fustrated.
The new Emirates Lounge at Fiumicino airport is super! You can board directly from the lounge. Thank you Emirates.

The airport is a bit messy (especially the new babage pick-up at arrival), and since Lufthansa Group moved to the extreme side of T1 (and no longer T3), it becomes quite a walk (10mins) to the D-gates.
This being said, the airport is very easily reachable by train (Regional and Leonardo Express), Fast Lane at T1 (Alitalia) was indeed very fast, and the Star Alliance lounge at the airport is very comfortable, with a good drinks service.

Undergoing renovation, but the bagage pick up is now split in two. Very bad signage and very unclear what direction you need to take. Lots of other passengers ended up at the wrong bagage pick up, and there was no way to go back to the other side.
If you have access to the Alitalia lounge, well worth the visit. Great food in a relaxing environment.

While Fiumicino is claiming to have won the best airport in Europe vote, I can not really imagine how... I fly from FCO at least 2x a month and  majority of flight always leaves late, toilets are dirty and compared to other airports there is no choice of food except for bad pizza and panini. It is not an ugly airport but the service is poor.

Generally OK airport. No complaints other than rather than having to buy bottled water I would like to see a bottle filling station like they become common in many other airports. Hence only 3 stars for facilities.

Have not been to FCO for some time, there are some improvements but "free WiFi" is a joke.
Food and coffee shops could also be better, considering this is Italy, the level is not representative...

L'aeroporto è bello. Tutte luci. Ma, come al solito, c'è sempre qualche cosa che non funziona. Questa volta dei tornelli per i controlli automatici dei passaporti per i viaggiatori EU ne funzionavano soltanto tre (gli altri erano in manutenzione) con la conseguenza di  una interminabile coda.

One of the best airports in Europe. Of course It's not like CDG or LHR but It's hard to deny that It's improving, unlike the city of Rome itself (sadly!) .
They always improve and build something new.
Toilets are modern and very efficient.
Horrible transfer security check - no business fast lane and freaky old equipment. Lounges were under renovation

mmigration in Rome is a breeze with no question being asked and a nice smile, "welcome to Italy". My luggage also arrived without incident at Rome and only 15 minutes after landing , I was outside on the streets met by my Italian friend Aldo. To be able to fly the Biman DC10 makes a good strong finish of the year 2006 for me. I have been long wanted to fly them and it was easily the best of my 2006 flights. I would like to thank sincerely to the captains and crews on Biman. The extraordinary memory on this flight will last for a long time. In my view, a DC10 classic is far better than 100 routine flights on modern airplanes.
Rather chaotic airport, but very well served by Public Transport. New Star Alliance lounge is a great improvement.

Been a few times, nice airport, not the most modern however good facilities. Train service direct to and from Roma Termini that takes about half an hour. Not overly large and easy to find your way around with staff helpful even in emergencies and tough situations.

Airport is big, all the facilities needed are there, though I had a problem departuring from the airport, not that many buses later in the evening. The Wifi was not easily reachable, but people and employees were trying to help out.

на шатле от Ватикана добрались до аэропорта. шатл пришел по расписанию. долго идти от остановки шатла в терминал 1. на табло были указаны стойки регистрации некорректно - работники аэропорта перенаправили к другим. у других стоек была очередь. после досмотра минут 20 шли до выхода (с переездом на метро между терминалами) - короче расстояния огромны.

놀라운 공항....
택스리펀부터 놀라게 하더니.

아직도 모르겠다.

Overcrowded, clearly in need of renovations to accomodate the number of passengers (and that was early June, not the peak season!).
Not very efficient airport. Crowded and no internet check-in possible. (At least the day I travelled)

Everything was simply great, but when you're not travelling with SkyTeam airlines the baggage claim takes ages. Avia Partner (the handler) communicate after 30 minutes that they have changed tape, simply annoying and it's such a shame because FCO improved so much.

This airport is getting better and better. It's been renovating in a modern and efficient way. Very easy to move through, you can find everything you need thanks to the big amount of shops. Overall I have to say that the new interior's look it's good.
We had to take a taxi, because considering the prices and how hard it is to take the train, it was much more convenient. Very few people at that time, which made it a pleasant experience.
Train from FCO to Rome is very expensive and not good at all, stations are very ugly and with no elevators or escalators.
Customs was unacceptably slow - probably 45 minute wait in a queue, and we arrived early for the flight. Otherwise nothing special about the airport.

The only airport in Italy with a "global" feeling. Lots of shops, small walking distances. Connection with the city is good (by train, don't even think about taking a taxi!)
But... problems (fires in the surroundings, fires *inside* the terminal, strikes, weather...) are quite common and at the minimum deviation from the standard everything collapses like a house of cards, with huge delays, unhelpful personnel, no updates, chaos.
Keep an eye to the GATE Number because they will change it 30 minutes before the departure time. Terminal 2 at the moment is CLOSED, use Terminal 3 instead.
Fiumicino Airport is getting better and better every time I use it. Clean, modern, full of shops and with a lot of choice about food.
My neckpillow got lost in the luggage depository!!! Grrrr very disappointed. Also huge queues at the passport control, I had to squeeze to the front :(
Great facilities and services at the Rome airport. However, the queue at Immigration can be really long and time-consuming to get through.
Priority pass issued by Alitalia means that you have the 'honour' to board the airport bus first and then to wait in the bus until half of the economy class boards too.
Después de 3 vuelos, en este que era el último, me quitaron la pasta de dientes casi vacía por tener más de 100ml.
Big variety of shops, modern and clean toilettes, but unefective air-condition and small number of seats.WiFi was often faltering.
Slow service, our gate almost without sitting places. Airplane was waiting 30min, meanwhile 4 staff people was playing with computer instead of boarding passengers.

Don't travel with checked in baggage through this airport because they even can not manage the transfer in 3 HOURS!
It happened 3/3 times!
The airport service is a shame!!!
WOW! The new look of T3 by night and the newest extention of Gates E, what a beauty! Finally a great airport for Rome.
Impressed by the latest improvements of this airport. Everything was fast and efficient, the new look is top notch.

Get by bus right to terminal 3. Had a good croissant as breakfast. Check-in has no lines, also they speak little russian and gave me a window seats as I asked. When it was time to go to the gates, i found that I lost a wallet at waiting zone, but went to police and after 5min they give it me back, i was so happy! Had horrified by security-check line, but it didn't take so long. Get to the gate just 5min before boarding begins. No displays after security check in case gate changed.
Very easy to understand where to go, staff will guide you to immigration. Have to ask staff to find a bus platform. You have a big choice of ways to Rome. Wifi works even outside, helped me a lot.
No lounge for star alliance member. Yes, LH members can use the AF's lounge, but german wing's uses cannot.
Very intricate transfer between terminals, in consequence of we were also late to our flight. But delicious and cheap food in cafe of Italian cuisine!

FCO airport as it is was quite a good experience when it came to the departure the side.

At least it was less hectic than it was when I have arrived. Terminal 3 as it is, is quite comfortable and big enough to be able to spend a nice amount of time while you're waiting for your flight.

All in all it is a great airport to fly from

While this has been the first time I have used FCO I have to say it didn't amuse me, as much as I wanted.

The arrival was great, and the bus service from the plane to the gate area was fast, and it was available almost immediately after our arrival.

Though the arrival part of Terminal 3 was not the most organized places on Earth, as it is a bit too small, for the amount of people arriving to the same terminal in the morning hours.

I'm more than happy with the departure side though, as that is airy, and spacious. But on a warm day like today (10/10/16) the inside of the building could get really heated up.
So you'll have to move in between the departure waiting areas if you don't like the sauna feeling.

Other than that it is quite a good airport, with great transport links not just to Rome, but also to other parts of Italy as well.

A bit older building.
A fast connection to my next flight was possible (transfer within 50 minutes after landing).
Our bags didnt get to our transit flight and so we had to wait for thwm a view days on our final destination

Leaving from the "US departures" terminal was absolute hell. Get there 3-4 hours early, because they had only 1 immigration person stamping passports for ALL the passengers on flights heading to the US. People had missed or were near missing their flights due to the line, that backed up into their security check area. Finally a 2nd person showed up. You have to take like 2 buses to get around. Terrible how it's laid out.

Motorway from city to FCO busy but fast moving. BA check-in took a couple of minutes. Security  fast but passport control was a joke, 20 minutes to look at 3 passports. Plenty of shops and cafes in terminal, BA lounge v. good (even has a smoking area!).

This airport has no relaxing areas where you have comfortable seats and tables. No power connections as well, which makes working on a laptop with low battery almost impossible. Other airports like AMS have much better facilities for this.

Terrible check-in process.  VAT refund area for Terminal 5 was closed. They make you take a bus to G gates then a train back to H gates, going through 2 security checkpoints to do so.  Each time you have to take out all of your electronics and stick them into small plastic bags that rip when you try to put your iPad in them.  Forget about even trying to stick in a full size SLR camera, and or a normal sized laptop

Fiumicino is confirmed as one of the worst international airports. Flights in perpetual delay, lack of information, unprepared staff, poor organization. This is the gateway to Italy and it doesn 't give, to the travellers, a positive image of the country.

Very much improved within last two years, and quite some parts nicely renewed/refurbished.
Finally public WiFi that functions and logs in without hassle. Finally charging stations on several points available.
Some further improvements and will be eligible for 5 stars...

Quite an old airport, fairly basic, but it does the job.
Good local transport connections including a rail link to the city that is just outside of the terminal.
The only big letdown of Fiumicino in Terminal 1 is that the foodcourts all sell te same. Just a simple little pistolett can not be bought, only big ones. Thats a pitty
huge queei at the secyrity check but they handled it with professionalism and it took just 30 minutes t pass through the secyritiy check
These guys lost our luggage and it took them 12 hours to find it, but this happened after i made a serious scandal, shouting and etc.
I was in Leonardo da Vinci-Flumicino in January. It was really cold! Air heating not work! Outside was 2 degrees.

Huge and decent airport, which I think is going to become much better after new terminals and boarding areas will be built. Actually there are a lot of renovations going on. I think it's one of the most busy airports in Europe, aircrafts must queue up for long before takeoff. Nicer terminals and new lounges is what misses.

80 out of 100 times you will be desembarked not through a finger on a EU flight. This means 2 to 3 buses waiting (when they are on time) below the plane. Most usually parking spots for planes are quite far. Seems more a bus station rather than a modern airport, with dozens of trucks going back and forth. Very uncomfortable, especially when weather dos not helps.

Quite far from the city, but decently connected. In my experience, there are frequently delays after landing waiting for the stairs to disembark (!!) or the buses; long rides by shuttle; not the most polite personnel at the gates. Can get quite crowded. Extremely high prices for taxis, as usual in Italy, and aggressive driving by most of the cab drivers.

There have been renovations going on in the terminals in the last few months...the staff are working hard to keep up with the other major european airports...once there was a bigger gap between Rome's main airport and the others, now it's getting reduced.My personal experience has been absolutely positive.

Rome Fiumicino is a very good airport...Wi fi is very ok... it necessary do an access in local wireless. Food is everywhere and overall excellent and very good. Check in is very quickly and terminal are very facilities.

This is an airport in dire need of renovation, of both its facilities and its staff attitude to travellers.
Security was pretty much standard - thorough, which was reassuring.

However, when airside the experience is truly awful.
If you have an early morning departure, you'll find little to eat other than panini's or croissants as the restaurants don't open until 8 am, despite the signs telling you they open at 7.
There's little seating at the café's that there are and what is there is unclean and in poor condition. Coffee's are served in small take-away cups, expensive and nowhere near the quality you'll find in the city.
Worst of all, the staff simply don't care.
Don't bother with the wifi, it simply isn't there. For a departures area that's carrying high end brands in its shops, its a very dismal and unpleasant experience.

If you can avoid it at all, then do so..

Raggiungere il Leonardo Da Vinci in auto nel tardo pomeriggio significa mettere a dura prova la propria pazienza. Il traffico è tale che dal centro di Roma ci si può mettere anche un'ora e mezza. I treni sono leggermente più veloci ma del tutto inadatti al tipo di servizio. Sono particolarmente scomodi nelle sedute e chi ha una valigia o un trolley non sa dove metterlo. 
Ampia scelta di negozi, bar e fast food all'interno del T1, wifi solo a pagamento, varchi sicurezza per la maggior parte chiusi e con i nastri che si inceppano.

The trip was so boring, the audio system was broken and the meal was terrible... I don't know why Alitalia provide a low cost service... FCO was only my transfer airport so I don't have informations about the check-in and the security check. The Alitalia service loss a lot in the last years.

reaching the airport is very easy from Rome: there is the a fast train going from roma termini to fiumicino airport station. My flight departed from T2 and this terminal is the smallest. There isn't so much to do, there are a few shops but the security  check is very fast. 6.5 out of ten

Connecting with a flight from Palermo turned out to be a nightmare. You are forced to transfer on busses several times that take you all over the airport. We then had to join a massive crush of people waiting to get passports checked as only two people were on duty. This led to angry scenes as people tried to push in as they thought they were missing their flights. 

Passport control staff are unprofessional  and rude (passing through on a previous trip the staff seemed more interested in playing whatsapp than checking identities)

The food iat most of their shops s slop and inedible and served by zombie like staff

The terminals are claustrophobic and overcrowded.


This is a poorly run horrible airport that is a poor gateway to Italy... Calling it third world is an insult to third world countries...
Spore opóźnienie przy wpuszczaniu na pokład z winy obsługi.Duże i dobrze skomunikowane ze sobą terminale, łatwe dojście  na pociąg do miasta, dużo połączeń autobusowych w akceptowalnych cenach.

This airport is alright.  Customs is very quick if that is a concern.  I am unsure about the parking situation.  It can get a little confusing with the bus/taxi situation.  If you do take a taxi make sure it's a legit; the cars for the taxi service of the City of Rome are white and can be recognized by the sign "TAXI" on the car top and by the identifying licence number on the doors, on the back and inside the car.

No lounge for business class, expansive and a lot of people that ask you money for unesco, insurances or whatever. I had a connection of 3 h and there was not a single place where resting or eating proper food at a reasonable price . Wi Fi didn't work

Cancel it from yours stop over ... Unkind staff, dirty toilets, chaotic terrible experience. To change from international to domestic flights you need a good pair of shoes.. Wifi non always warking... This is supposed to be the best airport in Italy

Chaotic expansive (1 small coffee 1.20€) no food places just fashion shops, the duty free is hopeless. Terminal G is terrible. Wifi did not work, food in the lounge was very poor. The aircraft was parked very far from the terminal and we need 10 minutes, by bus, to get to the plane

Confusion, no wifi hopeless airport.. The transfer from domestic to non Shengen flights is organised with busses and it seems we must cross the Roman Empire to get to terminal G. I can see just fashion shops and not many kiosks for food. The lounge is nice but the food poor and limited . Passport check very quick done.

Not stable wifi at terminal 3. 
But Airport is so good. very comfortable and convenient. Business Lounge at a very high level, which distinguishes this from other airport in Southern Europe.
From the minuses - a delay of airport security. As a result - an extra turn in the area of inspection.

Comparing a european airport like FIUMICINO to an argentinian one, like EZEIZA. EZEIZA Wins clearly.

The airport is dirty, not organizated, and the personal is really impolite.



Please do not worry if the personell looks you like an ebola victim with their masks/mouthcovers. say: Why you look me like an ebola patient? if your airpor is more dirty than haiti.

Getting to the airport is not the best since the buses aren't very easy to find. Food and retail is extremely expensive, almost hilarious. Lounge is small and almost in ruins with malfunctioning doors and lights. Immigration is antiquate, with the automatic gates present but closed, and a policeman doing the checks without even looking at your face while talking with his colleague about gossip. Didn't use baggage claim, it used to be bad in the past, but perhaps now it became better

When i was there, there are still reconstruction going on due to the fire last month (May2015). For that i will not comment further. My experience with the airport staff were cold but their wifi were excellentr

Canceled flights are not displayed on the scoreboard. One notices only at check-in that the flight was canceled. Signage is misleading parking and air gates are denoted by the same letters. Staff is incompetent and rude. Free Wi-Fi is available only for one hour.

Probably the worst airport I've ever been to. I had to go through it to get a connecting flight to Milan Linate, and the experience couldn't have been worse. Getting from one plane to another was a truly epic saga, with rude staff, poor signing, and only ONE person working on immigration and passport control. We almost lost our connecting flight while waiting in line.

Tricking vending machines, beware!
They get the cash banknotes, make noise like giving back rest in coins and you get NOTHING!
Very long lines waiting for security check early in the morning flights of about 7 AM

Absolutly fantastic Airport. A large one. Went with bus shuttle to the Terminal, some minutes to the next gate and continued our way to london. Rom ist absolutly considerable as Airport. There is no doubt: One of the best ones i have seen.

Not as easy to find your way especially since no one feels obliged to speak English and expects you to speak fluent Italian. I found that very disturbing..

The place was remodeled when I flew so this added to the confusion

Bagge claim was smooth which I didn't expect from an Italian airport ...

FCO Roma Fiumicino è un aeroporto molto comodo da raggiungere tramite bus/treno e A90. L'aerostazione e molto grande e curata, bagni puliti (T1/T2).Un pò di disorganizzazione nell'arrivo bagagli e nel controllo passaporti .Voto 8/10
Wifi gratuito.

It's very busy and hectic, and a good indicator of what Rome itself will be like. There's free wifi, which is nice for when you're disembarking and want to catch up on your emails.

Although there are multiple ways of reaching the city centre, the easiest and fastest way is to hop on the Leonardo Express. It's around 15 euros, and takes just 15 minutes to reach Roma Termini.

Airline lounges all close around 8pm
Poor airport facilities
There can be long lines @ security checks but you can purchase for 5€ a pass for a Fast Track
if you are not flying to Rome try to avoid FCO, if you are flying to other Italian destinations try to use other european Hubs.

slow security control at the arrival out of europe. T3 old terminal by they are working on it, full on shops...for shopping you see that you are transiting in Italy. T2 nothing special and T1 renewed and very nice, expecially from the departures.

We spent 1 hour in a passport control queue for "other passports", while people with EU passports were passing very fast, no queuing at all - officers doing nothing. Awful. Flight from Moscow. Very long way to a baggage claim if your flight is located for line 10-11. Airport is under reconstruction, which does not affect passenger traffic, but is seen from the plane.

The Terminal 1 is very good now. Check-in procedures and security checks are fast, boarding procedures are good, and there is a large choice of shops in the Terminal. Much bettere than Terminal 3 at the moment.

Too much crowded and it seemed personal staff wasn't too concentrated, as all the check-in desks had huge lines. It eas not very clean, and some areas on the corners were accumulating dust. This review and rating is for T3, not for T1 and T2 which are much better.
Even though the access is still a pain, T3 (LCC Terminal) is getting better.
The terminal itself is fairly tiny which makes it easy to use (no chance to get miss) and less crowded.
Personally I love the food lounge of T3, cheap and delicious. Retail service is also growing. There is a few tax-free shops located in the side of international flights (even one upon arriving). For domestic, there is only one shop and a few vending machines after security check.
As a LCC terminal (used to be a cargo terminal in the past), do never expect its lounges and facilities. But it is simple and easy, just the same as LCC.

I hadn't been to Japan for 25 years and I remembered Narita as a convenient airport. Compared to many airports in Asia, I therefore was surprised by the general impression I got when flying in today. Immigration/customs are OK, but the service area once you arrive is very confusing, few signs in English, difficult to find your way... You have to search for a long time before finding an ATM which is not just a money exchange machine. I tried to buy a data SIM card for my pocket WiFi router but that turned out to be impossible, there are some parameters which do not configurate automatically (whereas this works in countries as diverse as Russia or Australia). Wanting to buy a Narita Express ticket, the automatic ticketing machines do not take foreign credit cards, and even at the counter my Visa card did not work so I had to pay with cash!!! Where did the smooth, seamless Japanese automation go?

November 2015:

Honestly they can't build the new Mexico DF airport fast enough.  Benito Juarez is in dire straights.  

The airport is 24/7 but the transportation between the two terminals either isn't (the train certainly isn't) or too complicated (I speak Spanish and still can't figure out the intra-terminal bus) so if you're connecting at night and need to switch terminals, better grab a taxi.  

There's no wifi that's free to foreigners which is embarrassing.  There's a workaround but it's not great.  Basically there's 1 network (sorry I forget which) that you can connect to that is for Mexicans who subscribe to whatever cell phone company it is, when you don't have credentials to log in it still gives you like 5-15 minutes of internet connectivity by accident.  Worked for me on my MacBook, but not my iPhone.  I did this repeatedly to get things done.  With status I can use the lounge, but it's not open 24/7.

I gave facilities 3 stars because they keep the place pretty clean at least at night, somehow I've never been there during the day.  There's 7-11/Circle K open 24/7 at both terminals, both have some decent indoor/outdoor seating, though you will always find people sleeping on the floor. Terminal 2 has a restaurant that's 24/7 as well that serves decent food and liquor (not sure what time liquor goes til) and it's not horribly expensive.  

If you've arrived after a long day of flying and still have some left, bring a change of clothes.  You won't find a cheap shower/hotel right here, so if you wanna leave not feeling like a dirt bag, a change of clothes REALLY helps.  

If you're taking the train between terminals beware of guys offering to help.  They don't work for the airport, or if they do, they aren't free.  I'm a physically capable young man who speaks Spanish and I was being offered some help to make the train, I thought oh great he's just one of those airport helper types.  Then he took my bag up the escalator...MY CARRYON 15lb bag...as if I couldn't do that?  Then he asked for a tip.  I get it, he's working...but I didn't need help, and I told him he didn't need to take my bag but he insisted.  Not only did I not want to tip him, but when I told him I had no pesos (I was connecting for 5 hours, why would I have local cash?) he said he accepts all currencies.  I had just come from Colombia, going home to Canada, I don't carry much if any cash in either country so all I had was plastic...he walked off in a big huff angry that he had wasted 5 minutes with me.  

Overall this airport is a pretty miserable experience.  Signage can be extremely poor, again speaking Spanish I'm not sure if English is a problem here, I'd hope not, it's Mexico after all.  But anything other than English and you might be in trouble.  There's banks and currency exchanges open 24/7 but not that much else.  Service here is poor outside of the restaurant I spoke of.  It's also run down and being renovated...WHY?  You're already building a new airport so renovating duty free seems stupid.  Maybe they'll use this airport as an LCC one for VivaAirbus or something.  

The gates are a bit of a disaster too.  Everyone wants to use tiered boarding systems but the gates are too crammed to really accomplish that.  When AA, DL, AV and AC all have international flights departing within 15 minutes of each other in the same tiny corner of the airport, there's nowhere left to sit and boarding while quick, is chaotic.  With a big airfield taking off can take some time as well.  

My final complaint...customs and baggage claim.  Customs at Terminal 2 is nice, it's well lit, well divided, it's new, it's fairly quick.  Baggage claim is slow but I've seen worse areas to be standing in. 

Terminal 1 is literally a bunker in what feels like the basement of the airport.  There's support beams in the middle of the lineup and you're never quite sure if the building will collapse on your head.  There's no customs forms here, so you better hope you remembered to bring the one from on the plane.  It's also somewhat of a mad dash to get in here, because despite having full international flights arriving late at night there'll still only be 3-4 customs workers on shift...yet the duty free next to it has 4-5.  The lineup never seems to take THAT long, but I also make sure I'm never near the back of it.  

After that baggage claim can be a chore.  It seemed to me normal connection rules for baggage don't apply here.  I was told not to pick up my bag, then security officials insisted I had to, then my bag didn't show up and they said it must've been lost, then upon talking to the airline, they said I didn't need to receive it.  Again, all of this was done in intermediate to high level Spanish, I know when I'm not understanding and this wasn't the case.

Connecting at this airport, should be avoided if you can, ESPECIALLY if you're making a connection between 2 different airlines, or heaven forbid 2 different alliances.  Also check the wiki page because no all alliances stick to one terminal like normal. Copa (Star Alliance) is T2 while Lufty/AC/Avianca are all T1.  So making that connection means you need to retrieve your bags, transfer terminals (with train or not, depending on time of day) and re-check in on the other side.

T3 at London Heathrow is among the weariest terminals through which I've ever flown. And that list includes Terminal B at LaGuardia  and T5 at JFK back in the late TWA days when the air conditioning frequently didn't work. So when I say T3 at Heathrow is tired, I mean it. The corridors are narrow and stuffy. The layout creates numerous "crossovers" that necessitate waiting at sealed corridors for other passengers to deplane before you can get to your own. (And heaven forbid you decide you want to go back to the other end of the concourse for a bagel. Odds are you'll be waiting again.) The individual gate hold areas are security isolated from the rest of the concourse, which is uniquely unpleasant. And even the vaunted duty free mall is crowded, dark, labyrinthine, and generally unpleasant. What's more, they do not post your gate assignment until an hour before your flight in an effort to keep travelers trapped in the generally sordid confines of the duty free dungeon. If you have another choice of airport, use it.

I use Heathrow Airport on average every 2 weeks and I have to say it’s the best airport in London. That’s not to say it’s without faults cause there’s many! But if your coming to or from London... this is your best bet. It dosen’t stack up to other European airports like Schipol, Luxembourg, Geneva or Paris CDG, and comes no where even remotely close to world class airports like Singapore Changi, Zurich or Munich. However it will get you from A-B with minimal hassle depending on luck. 

Getting to and from the airport is fairly easy with taxis and Uber’s available. There is also busses and the Tube (your best bet) on the Piccadilly line straight from London. There are tube stops for Terminal 1,2&3, Terminal 4 and Terminal 5 so make sure you get off at the right one and beware, Terminals 1,2&3 is a long walk to any of the Terminals. Terminal 1 is closed however but Terminal 2 and 5 are the most modern and look nice clean and new with good architecture. Terminals 3 and 4 are slightly older but still very acceptable. In each terminal it is well signposted and depending on the time of day security and check in aren’t too bad, but expect half an hour for both at worst. 

The restaurant and shops situation is a double edged sword... while they are nice and luxury, I can’t imagine many people can afford these places other than just look, and also who’s buying a TV or a MacBook in an airport? The food situation isn’t much better, most of the time you can only stomach a quick snack and it has to be takeaway. With the exception of a Pret A Manger, Costa, WHSmiths or Starbucks your only option is to have a sit down expensive meal. Signage is good, although only  in English. Announcers however do make announcements in English and the language of the country the said flight is traveling too. 

The gates usually have enough seats although expect to stand if you are late. Staff are generally friendly and helpful. Sometimes you can breeze through and other times it can be really annoying. Also beware of where your gate is as sometimes it can be quite far away. This is especially important if you are in terminal 5, which has 2 satellite terminals (5B & 5C) which you need to take an underground train too which takes a further 15 minutes. You will know this if your gate starts with either a B or a C. In Terminal 5 if your gate is A23 then you are in the main terminal. If it’s B23 or C23 then you have to take the train. European flights almost always tend to be in the main terminal as it’s more important people get their fast. 

Beware if there is anything other than completely normal weather your flight could be delayed or cancelled... 1000s of flights get cancelled each year for the most pathetic reasons that would make the Swiss (like me), Norwegians, Canadians or Russians die with laughter. 

All in all though it’s a fairly decent airport and definitely your best bet in London by a mile...

BA Lounge at Terminal5 needs a big up grade. Maybe BA should look at the Lounge they share with Qantas in Hong Kong to learn how it should be done.

Security was quick and easy, the terminal had some good eateries and it was great seeing a variety of smaller aircraft and larger aircraft from the terminal. Wi-Fi worked well and was quick enough and it was an all-round comfortable experience while waiting for our flight.
London Heathrow is a great airport. Easy to get around, helpful and friendly staff and nice eateries make waiting for your flight great.
My first time to make use of the bus service for connections between terminals (T5 to T4 in this case). Lovely service!

Excellent aéroport ! Beaucoup d'espace.

It is very easy to get to Heathrow, There is many bus, train and tube services to your flight. I was flying with Aer Lingus to Cork so I got to use the brand new Terminal 2. Check-In was very quick but going into security took over 20 minutes. once through security there was a wide range of Shops and restaraunts but it was just very busy. The WiFi worked perfect and there was always toilets nearby. I wasnt in the lounge so I cant say much about that. Also I didnt go through Immigration as I was flying from Ireland, a great feature after having to get up early and saves you from waiting in a long queue, This may be for other EU nations. Baggage Claim was slow though, It took me a long time to get my bag off the belt. I rate it 4 stars due to how busy it was and long waiting times but overall a Clean and well designed airport.
Terminal 5 is nice,good transport links,I love Heathrow,my favourite airport.BA use this terminal,but shops very busy and VERY expensive.
Heathrow is a fantastic airport. Good stores, clean facilities, service minded staff and modern technology.
Heathrow Terminal 5 is spacious, beauctiful and you don't need to walk a million kilometres to get to your gate

This review is for T3. Good facilities and wifi. Passport control was a nightmare. 70 minute wait to get through. Over 20 counters; however, only 2 were manned for about 20 minutes with 3 more reinforcements about 20 minutes into our wait.

2 hours in the queue to border control while less than 20% of the stations were manned.  If you are unlucky enough to arrive at T3, and have no checked bags, go through flight connections to T2 and do your border formalities there.

Arrived at Terminal 3 at around 0700. There was barely any traffic which I was impressed with, and the drop off area wasn't crowded at all. Met with the rest of my group and check-in opened promptly at 0730. Check in was fine, albeit only manned by two check in agents, but it was sufficient nonetheless. Security check was also fine, and then made it to the departures lounge. 

The lounge did seem pretty small/cramped however the selection of food and retail was good enough. One note I would make is that Terminal 3's ceilings are very low and the buildings lack a lot of natural light, which doesn't help the feeling of being cramped if I'm honest. This was different in the gate area (gate 32) however, where there was a lot of seating and good places to planespot. Overall it was a good enough experience to prepare me for the 8 hour flight to Nairobi ahead of me.
Skyteam lounge is amazing..quiet, big, with lot of delicious food and drinks..and also the massage..we really enjoy the stay here.

After transfer security (why?) transfer passport check (why?) sent everyone to the transfer desk even if it was totally unncessesary. It's bad enough to have to queue twice for little apparent reason, but to be sent into a third unnecessary queue is just a colossal waste of time and frustration.

The airport is expensive and pretty, but security here is a pain. They really go over everything with a fine tooth comb, enforcing the letter of the law - spirit of the law be damned. I let's just too much. Their protocols need to be updated to reflect what has been found to be effective in deterring terrorism rather than adhering to 16 year old ideas religiously. I generally avoid transferring here, but sometimes it just can't be helped.

On the return, a very long walk from the gate to customs, which was also cleared within minutes, and even more amazingly, the luggage was also being delivered. Full marks all around.

The best airport I've ever seen. Essentially a mall with every airline club imaginable, The Queen's Terminal sets the bar high for it's competition.

Amazing airport experience, quick, easy and painless! Love the lounge at Terminal 3 for British Airways!

Terminal 3 efficient. Connection from T5 to T3 not great - crowded bus and have to re-clear security.

Well, what can I say? Terminal 5 and even Terminal 5 Pier C is just as good as it was since I first flew from here.

Of all the immigration experiences in the world Heathrow T5 is worst, long waits and very misrable and patronising immigration officers!
Impossible de déposer les bagages plus de trois heures avant le décollage. Un seul restaurant au service épouvantable (café rouge, cuisine correcte), le Terminal 4 est à fuir autant que possible.

Fast lane was busy, but at all other immigration/transfer counters was no one. Hence I switched. Apparently that disturbed someone's morning rest..., as the transfer lady started to snap at me... Sad.

Heathrow is a good big airport but I was completely shocked by the passport control. I know its a big hub and a lot of people want to visit London but standing in line for more than THREE HOURS to pass the passport control is too much.

Bearing in mind the current terror threat, it was slightly concerning that I didn't have to go through any immigration when arriving off a long haul flight, but apart from that there are no complaints.

Terminal 4 was busy, but clean and reasonably efficient.  Etihad staff at airport unable or willing to keep us in the picture as to delay.

Extremely large airport. Flew in from Dublin on BA 827 to Term 5. Shuttle from Term 5 to Term 3 is direct w/ 1 additional Term 5 stop. Security was a breeze.  2:45 minute layover gave me about 1:30 to spare before boarding. LHR is massively expansive but efficiently run. Lots of uniformed ground personnel easily noticeable and friendly if you need helped you walk thru Term 5 to shuttle. Shopping and restaurants in Term 3 great.
Lovely airport very modern amazing loads of services very cheap to get to you can take a bus for about £2 or underground

no smoking area

departure from C gates, requiring to take the shuttle

We liked the transportation from the Long Stay parking to the Terminal and the quick check-in with AA.

Quick passport check and very professional boarding with AA. 
We didn't used any Lounge in LHR.

First time in LHR T4, we had stayed in the Hilton Hotel next to the terminal as we knew it would be convenient and only a short walk. Less than 10 mins for an average pace walker- allow longer if with children. We took advantage of this and dropped our bags of before breakfast the following morning, allowing us to enjoy a leisurely breakfast knowing our bags were already checked in. We had no problems and faced no major queues at security, and were able to move through to the departure lounge with ease. Very clean and tidy and GENERALLY easy to navigate. Well done LHR, another pleasing experience!

It is very frustrating that Heathrow information boards will not give you your gate until the last minute, just to force you to stay in the shopping area. 
Well sometimes people don't want to shop. Sometimes people are stressed and tired enough from the journey that they just want to get to their gate well in time instead of having to rush.

The Heathrow Connect train is my best option for getting home. Pity it's situated in a freezing dark tube with hardly any seats at the end of a long walk (or a long wait for the Express train from T5) where you may be waiting for 30 minutes. The way to the trains is also badly signposted in T5 and at the platform they sometimes make different announcements simultaneously from two speakers. Not a very welcoming experience although the Connect trains are fine unless you arrive at rush hour when they become crammed commuter trains after leaving the airport.
Nya terminal 2 är riktigt bra. Ljust och snyggt, bra service på alla ställen. Lufthansas lounge är väldigt bra.
If you have Star Alliance Gold status, LHR T2 is heaven! Among the lounges, United Lounge is the best!

The brand-new Heathrow T2 is a HEAVEN, if you have Star Alliance Gold status. With Gold customer check in, Gold Track security line, all the process from check in to boarding can't be smoother. And recommend United lounge, which is modern and spacious, and has friendly staff and great food and liquor selection.
A huge airport, so allow plenty of time between arrival and boarding. It's very easy to get to and there are plenty of facilities.
Long transit time (bus+walk) from T2-T3, two hour connection, not much time to relax and settle in the SQ lounge.
Close connection between T2 and T3, bus and long walk but had a chance to eat in Virgin Lounge, easily the best airline lounge.

Flew into T5 on BA from Edinburg, Heathrow Express and long walk to T2, quick checkin and security, straight to T2 duty free, sampled some single malts, went to SQ lounge. T2 duty free whiskey selection is outstanding.

Long walk from plane to immigration but no check-in luggage and FastTrack speeds entry into the UK. Then the fun began, took the Heathrow Express to T3 via Paddington Station (misread the signs), should have walked to T3 instead.

Long layover, went into London and back by Heathrow Express. Long, long walk to check-in/security and gate. Had my SQ Business Class boarding pass, went though security quickly. Heathrow has one of the best duty free shops, especially if you drink whiskey. Prices are excellent, selection is outstanding. Went to SQ First Class Lounge. Small compared to Virgin or Changi, limited selection in food and drink, seats are comfortable, recliner is the best place to camp out, shower/bathroom is good. Service is outstanding (I was the only one there for two hours).

Transit from Boston to Singapore. Checked bags to Singapore, planned a 12 hour layover so that I could do some business at Oxford and London. Long walks from plane to cab. Immigration was fast, Trusted Traveller/no bags. Great pub lunch in London at the Victoria Pub near Paddington (an easy trip on the Heathrow Express and back, worth eating there instead of staying in Heathrow). Used my LHR/SIN boarding pass to go through security, fast and easy.

landed in T2, 5 hr layover, transit to T3. Held a business interview in T3 check-in coffee shop. Boarding pass got me through security quickly, spent the time in Virgin lounge, best lounge! Heathrow lacks a reasonable bookstore (best is Compass Bookstore/SFO). Food is reasonably ok, best selection is Changi. Problem with Heathrow is the time between any two terminals. Can't risk a one hour connection between terminals. WiFi is intermittent.

If you keep track of steps, then Heathrow is your paradise. Transit between any two terminals will quickly get you to your 10,000 steps in a day. The downside is that flight connections can be a problem. Airport facilities and food options have improved in the last five years. Immigration line is fast in Fast Track/Trusted Traveller.
I was stopped two times by immigration officers asking questions as if I was some kind of criminal. Baggage claim was very slow. Had to wait more than 20 minutes to collect my baggage.

Landed at terminal 4. Renovation(+proper cleaning) works are obviously needed. Used internet station for a quick check. From under the escalator couple rats came out..had to quickly pick up my duffle bag and place it on a chair. Didn't look good at all for Europe's busiest airport. There should be more public transport option at night. Long wait for passport check.

I think there is too many up and down inside the Terminal 2 from the parking gate to the baggage claim. Also the immigration queue at the airport was very very long. It takes me about 2 hours to get out which is very small for A380. Staffs need to carry some suitcases out which make me find it hard to find.

Ease of changing terminals at LHR (usually T3 to T5 or reverse in my case) seem to depend a lot on the time of the day. Changing at 12 pm last time was a pain, while early afternoon (3 pm) transfer now was a charm.

When it comes to Heathrow Terminals 1-2-3 and you're there for the first time, it will feel like a never ending maze, as it is huge, and even though the signs are clear, you might need to run if you want to catch your flight. 
Luckily I have arrived quite early, but the check-in for the flight was already in place, but I wasn't sure in a few things when it came to my flight, so I just walked up to one of BA's Representatives to ask a few questions.

The customer service I have received was perfect, I still remember the smile, and the helpful behavior of Sonia, who helped me on that day, and offered further assistance should I require it.
So all in all that was perfect for me.

When it came to the boarding that was a bit more out of control, but that is not the fault of the staff, it is more on the passengers who were travelling on the same flight, as they were just not listening to the announcements.
I used only the terminal 5, but I liked it couse of its structure and his facilities. It is just a bit cold.
Decent experience, after disembarking immigration and customs was quite quick considering the volume of people, baggage claim was also quick and I was swiftly off home in no time.
London Heathrow terminal 3 has many restaurants and cafes to choose from, as well as many retails stores. The Emirates Business Lounge was exceptional as always!
Var och besökte Lufthansa Senator Lounge. Denna lounge är mycket bra med god mat gott och dricka samt luftiga och ljusa lokaler.

I hate Heathrow. Pure Hate.
Security checks take hours, humiliating everything a human has by searching EVERY person. Self service check-in not working. 
Shops at Heathrow are very expensive. Travel toward the airport takes an hour by Tube
Brilliant airport flew so many times even in peak season always so quick .Staff always so helpful.T5 is the best if your flighting BA but the other terminals our fine.So easy to get to on the tube .

One of the best airports I've been in. Extremely efficient in handling customers and flight departures are quite spot on. Easy navigation around the airport and all clearly sign posted. Transport links to and from LHR is quite good. Immgration services should have done a bit more to improve long queues.

One of the best airports I've been in. Extremely efficient in handling customers and flight departures are quite spot on. Easy navigation around the airport and all clearly sign posted. Transport links to and from LHR is quite good. Immgration services should have done a bit more to improve long queues.

Very nice and huge airport. It's one of the busiest I've ever been through. Terminal 5, to say the least, is fantastic. Wi-fi works perfectly and you find facilities everywhere. The one flaw perhaps is the long queue going out through customs. It takes very long!

Immigration/Customs and security are overburdened, unfriendly, and slow.  Business class lounges are small and packed, but have decent food and beverage offerings.  Allow a minimum of 2 hours for connections or you may miss your flight.

LHR is easily accessible by Tube Trains and the Heathrow Express. After arriving at Terminal 4, check in for your flight is easy to find and rather quick. Security checks are very thorough and everything is check. Even the slightest items are examined. There is an expansive range of Duty Free and many Cafes and Restaurants. Finally, there are several lounges available for frequent flyers that offer food, drinks and WiFi access. There is also WiFi around the Airport

As an Englishman to say I prefer to transit at CDG says what a poor experience LHR has become. Even as a native it is totally confusing, I feel really sorry for any visitors or transit passengers. Que's for security when transiting between terminal means you should plan on at least 3 hours between flights. They could learn a lot from AMS or ATL.

Heathrow is an ugly, overbearing, crowded and is basically user unfriendly. It's certainly an international hub but lacks in grace, is scandalously expensive and offers little in creature comforts. WIFI is irregular and patchy and expensive.

Check in was smooth and effortless for this trip. I checked in online the night before but opted to pick up my boarding pass at the airport. I was travelling hand baggage only which allowed me to easily used the self service kiosk and I had my boarding pass within 2 minutes. I previously wrote a review based on my experiences in the, soon to be defunct, terminal 1. I was not complimentary, criticising the long walks, deteriorating condition, and multiple security checks for domestic passengers. 

Thankfully, my flights have moved to T2. T2 is a revelation. Bright and airy, with plenty of shops and good quality food outlets. There is plenty of room in the terminal. Security has always been an absolute breeze since the move. Up to 4 hours free wi-fi, which is more than adequate for the majority of people and well above the industry standard. It worked very well indeed. 

I recently also transferred at LHR for the first time; between T2 and 3. The outward transfer (2-3) was extremely easy, with a bus awaiting me at my gate. The return was perhaps not quite as easy, with security and immigration checks taking a bit longer, but I still had plenty of time for the transfer itself (and to enjoy a nice breakfast on the way through!). 

On a side note, T3 is not quite as nice as T2, but still has plenty of outlets. The gate areas have low ceilings, poor lighting and feel very cramped, but thankfully they keep you there for as little time as possible and get boarding underway very quickly once you're at the gate. 

I recommend LHR for both passengers to/from London, and transferring passengers.

London Heathrow is a great, modern airport and our departure was great (apart from the 2 hour delay but that wasn't the airports fault). My only problem was on the way back. I had used "purple parking" to park my car. I had set off at T4 and landed on the way back at T2, I hadn't been told that United Airlines had moved so I had to take the Heathrow Express to T4 to get the car. When I finally arrived my car wasn't even there, it was back at T2. A nice member of staff offered to take me to T2 to collect it, so I accepted. I was dropped off at T2 short stay car park and the car wasn't there either. I had to phone "Purple Parking" and they said I would have to wait 15 minutes for the car to come. After 30 minutes the car finally came but because I was really late leaving because of the car parking company I was fined! My advice is don't use "Purple Parking" and just stay at a hotel where you can leave your car when your away and leave it at your hotel. Heathrow was good but definitely not Purple Parking.
